descript.abstract: Polygon Esri shapefile of designated areas for 8-hour ozone, for the revoked primary and secondary 1997 National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS). Nonattainment areas are geographic areas which have not met the 1997 NAAQS for 8-hour Ozone air pollution. Areas designated as "Attainment" are areas which formerly violated the NAAQS, but are now attaining. These standards are part of the Clean Air Act. More detailed information about NAAQS can be found at http://www.epa.gov/ttn/naaqs/. See Code of Federal Regulations, Section 40 Part 81, for detailed information about designated area boundaries.
descript.purpose: This data set is specifically designed for use with ArcGIS and related products. Data can be used for mapping and planning purposes.
descript.supplinf: Updated with Pechanga Reservation attainment designation, effective April 3, 2015 (80 FR 18120).

citeinfo.title: Ozone (8-Hr, O3) NAAQS Designations, Region 9, 1997, US EPA Region 9

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata

dataqual.logic: The spatial data is based on Public Land Survey System (PLSS), and political boundaries such as urban, county, state and tribal boundaries, thus the line work reflects the source; for example, PLSS or county.

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at http://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html)

enttyp.enttypd: Areas in EPA Region 9 designated for the 1997 8-hour ozone national standard

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: 1997 8-hour ozone standard area designations for US EPA Region 9

edom.edomvd: any area that does not meet (or that contributes to ambient air quality in a nearby area that does not meet) the national primary or secondary ambient air quality standard for the pollutant
any area that meets the national primary or secondary ambient air quality standard for the pollutant.

attr.attrdef: severity of pollution levels in a designated area, measured using design value concentrations.

edom.edomvd: Area violated the standard, but now is in attainment
Area has a design value of 0.187 ppm and above.
Area has a design value of 0.127 up to but not including 0.187 ppm
a has a design value of 0.120 up to but not including 0.127 ppm
Area has a design value of 0.107 up to but not including 0.120 ppm
Area has a design value of 0.092 up to but not including 0.107 ppm
Area has a design value of 0.085 up to but not including 0.092 ppm.

attr.attrdef: Name of county, if designated area is within a single county

edom.edomvd: The primary and seconadry 1997 8-hour ozone standard is 0.080 parts per million (ppm)
0.080 part per million, or 80 parts per billion (ppb)

attr.attrdef: Date designations are effective in regards to state implementation plan (SIP) implementation
Internet address for Federal Register notice
Length of feature in internal units.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

overview.eaover: Attribute information for areas in US EPA Region 9 designated according to the primary and secondary 1997 8-hour ozone (O3) national ambient air quality standards (NAAQS). More information is available at the Clean Air Act website, at http://www.epa.gov/air/caa/title1.html, and at the Green Book website, at http://www.epa.gov/oar/oaqps/greenbk/o8index.html

Nonattainment areas are geographic areas which have not met the 1997 NAAQS for 8-hour Ozone air pollution. Areas designated as "Attainment" are areas which formerly violated the NAAQS, but are now attaining. These standards are part of the Clean Air Act. More detailed information about NAAQS can be found at http://www.epa.gov/ttn/naaqs/. See Code of Federal Regulations, Section 40 Part 81, for detailed information about designated area boundaries.
